I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam is currently preparing a new 5-
year  socioeconomic  development  plan  (SEDP)  2006–2010,  for  approval  by  the  National 
Assembly by mid-2006. The SEDP will integrate the Government’s comprehensive poverty 
reduction and growth strategy (CPRGS) and Viet Nam Development Goals (VDGs). The SEDP 
will become Viet Nam’s national strategy for poverty reduction. The Government requested the  
Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide a technical assistance (TA) grant to help Dak Nong 
province to improve its poverty reduction and growth performance by strengthening capacity in 
socioeconomic development planning. The leaders of the province pursued the request during 
the seminar to discuss the findings of a joint study on sustainable poverty reduction and growth 
in the Central Highlands region by ADB and the Development Strategy Institute, Ministry of 
Planning and Investment (MPI), in Kom Tum in February 2005. A TA Fact-Finding Mission was 
fielded on 25–28 May 2005 to discuss with the Government counterparts and finalize the design 
of the TA. The Mission discussed and reached understanding with the Government on the goal, 
purpose  and  outputs,  methodology  and  key  activities,  cost  and  financing,  implementation 
arrangements,  and  outline  terms  of  reference  for  the  TA.  The  TA  design  and  monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.1  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Viet Nam’s impressive record of reducing poverty in recent years, particularly halving 
poverty within a decade, is largely attributed to its strong economic growth performance. The 
Government is committed to further reducing poverty down to about 16% of households by 
2010. It is, however, perceived that addressing the poor below the national poverty line would 
be  a  difficult  task  as  they  are  located  in  remote  highlands  and  mountains.  Similarly,  the 
impressive  gains  in  poverty  reduction  are  still  fragile  and  the  significant  proportion  of  the 
population,  especially  the  ethnic  minorities,  who  are  just  above  the  poverty  line  remain 
vulnerable to shocks, which could push them back below the poverty line. The Government has 
recognized that to sustain high economic growth and poverty reduction rates and to make them 
more socially inclusive, it would need to intensify its decentralization efforts by devolving more 
responsibilities  to  provinces  and  also  introducing  planning  reforms.2  In  the  process  of 
developing SEDP 2006–2010, the Government expects local governments to generate good 
quality plans as well as improve their capacity to implement those plans. As such the new SEDP 
will also incorporate elements of the CPRGS and VDGs. 
 
3.  ADB’s new country strategy and program (CSP), which is being aligned to the new 
SEDP,  envisages  supporting  the  Government’s  decentralization  efforts  of  devolving  more 
responsibilities to provinces. The CSP will have a sharper geographic focus on addressing 
issues  related  to  provincial-level  development  strategy,  policies  and  programs,  institutional 
capabilities,  and  investment  requirements,  especially  along  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion 
(GMS) economic corridors such as the East–West Economic Corridor and the Development 
Triangle.3  The  Central  Highlands  is  expected  to  benefit  from  these  regional  cooperation 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities (internet Edition) on 20 June 2005. 
2  Directive 33/ TTg dated 24 September 2004 by the Prime Minister, and Circular 2215/ MPI state the need to ensure 
quality economic growth through design of quality development plans. This objective requires new and innovative 
planning approaches. The 2004 budget law confirms that decentralization to local governments is required for 
resource allocation and investment. The draft new investment law also delegates decision making for business 
investment approval to lower levels. 
3  The Government of Viet Nam has developed a master plan for the Development Triangle and has strategized 
economic zoning for the Central Highlands region to link with the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR) 
and Cambodia.

2   
activities.  To  strengthen  the  regional  initiative  at  country  level,  including  the  results-based 
management approach, ADB will help local governments link up and catch up with the current 
development pace in the region as well as formulate results-oriented development plans. Pilot 
exercises in selected provinces are envisaged to generate a model that could be replicated in 
other poor provinces. They will also help ADB formulate its investment products using the TA 
results. 
 
4.  Dak Nong is among the poorest provinces in the Central Highlands and ranks 9th   
poorest among the 63 provinces of Viet Nam. Poverty prevalence in the province is estimated at 
48% of the households in 2004 as per the new definition of the Ministry of Labor, Invalids and 
Social Affairs (MOLISA). Dak Nong is a new province, created in 2004 and separated from Dak 
Lak, another of the poorest provinces in the region. Dak Nong has 6 districts and 52 communes. 
Half of the 52 communes are under the Government’s targeted program for poor communes 
(i.e. Program 135).4 A third of Dak Nong’s 418,000 population comprise ethnic minorities (both 
indigenous and recent immigrants) and constitute 31 different groups. With a total land area of 
651,000 hectares, coffee, rubber, cashew nuts, sugarcane, bauxite mining characterize the 
provincial economy. Many parts of Dak Nong often suffer from droughts and floods although the 
province is also endowed with hydropower potential. About 38 state-owned enterprises (26 of 
them  in  forestry),  294  private  enterprises,  952  household  businesses,  51  cooperative 
households, and 5 foreign enterprises (mainly in tea and coffee processing) operate in the 
province. The private sector contributes 88% of the province’s gross domestic product (GDP). 
 
5.  The key issues and challenges facing the province include (i) entrenched poverty, which 
is also related to the ethnic minorities that constitute 34% of Dak Nong’s population, and in-
migration; (ii) heavy dependence on traditional crops for livelihood; (iii) low level of investment; 
and (iv) lack of investment to exploit mineral (bauxite) resources. The issues are attributed to 
the fact that the province does not have the capacity nor the resources to design and implement 
appropriate development plans for delivery of basic services and mobilize resources for growth 
and  poverty  reduction.  As  such  the  province  is  constrained  to  effectively  support  the 
decentralization process. Dak Nong has very limited qualified staff and adequate administrative 
facilities. Though about a third of its personnel (from all departments) was transferred from Dak 
Lak during the separation last year and 20 new employee recruited recently to work at the 
Department of Planning and Investment (DPI), the personnel need urgent training to help 
implement  the  province’s  long-term  development  strategy  and  plans.  To  promote  fast  but 
inclusive growth and poverty reduction, the province needs qualified staff and well-resourced 
institutions to (i) create an environment conducive to business and investment enforced with 
appropriate laws and regulations; (ii) implement an effective system of public services (health 
care, education, basic services for the poor and ethnic minority); and (iii) maintain public goods, 
particularly physical infrastructure and natural resources. The provincial authority has shown a 
high level of commitment to changes and identified the needs for improvement, specifically in 
policies, institutional arrangements, and management capacity building to ensure sustainable 
poverty reduction and growth of the province to reach the level of other provinces in the region. 
 
6.  Since  2003,  ADB  has  been  supporting  the  Government’s  national  program  for 
strengthening provincial development planning and rolling out of the CPRGS at provincial level, 
                                                 
4  Program 135 (also referred to as support to poor communes) and the new poverty reduction program (formerly 
hunger eradication and poverty reduction [HEPR]) are the two major target programs of the Government. Phase 2 
of these programs will continue during 2006–2010 and will cover housing, education, health, credit support, 
infrastructure development, and capacity building. Decentralization in program implementation is required to 
improve its effectiveness.

3
mainly in Dak Nong and Gia Lai provinces through the TA4163-VIE and TA4252-VIE.5 These 
TAs and related activities have produced reports on lessons learned6 and training modules for 
socioeconomic planning at local levels. The reports stress the need for capacity enhancement 
of local officials in strategic planning, poverty and governance assessment, and investment 
needs survey. The reports also analyzed the importance of local ownership in implementing 
reforms and decentralization. The cited TAs have successfully raised awareness on the issues 
and helped local leaders to identify the needed follow-up actions.7 In that context, Dak Nong 
province was selected for its urgent needs and new administrative setup. To prepare the scaling 
of  planning  reforms  at  all  levels,  ADB  is  working  with  MPI,  together  with  other  official 
development assistance (ODA) partners, in preparing a planning handbook for socioeconomic 
development for use by provinces. The handbook will be useful for implementing the proposed 
TA.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The goal of the TA project is to support Dak Nong province in strengthening its capacity 
for socioeconomic development planning to improve poverty reduction and economic growth 
performance. Its purpose is to assist the provincial people’s committee (PPC) and department of 
planning  and  investment  (DPI)  in  (i)  training  key  officials  in  socioeconomic  development 
planning, results-based management, public investment planning, service delivery and other 
related  areas;  (ii)  implementing  its  SEDP,  particularly  in  preparing  annual  socioeconomic 
development plans, taking into account gender and ethnic minority dimensions; (iii) undertaking 
sector studies to identify investable projects and project/program financing alternatives (with 
state,  private,  and  foreign  resources);  and  (iv)  proactively  promoting  activities  for  inward 
investment. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.   The TA will adopt a process approach whereby the TA will be designed and its tasks 
implemented in close consultation with provincial leaders and government officials. The process 
approach will also provide learning-by-doing opportunities for provincial leaders and government 
officials. Top priority will be given to training provincial officials, including the recently recruited 
officers, in areas of strategic socioeconomic development planning, results-based management, 
resource  mobilization,  development  finance,  inward  investment  promotion,  agriculture 
diversification, and sustainable community development (including the ethnic minorities). The 
team  of  international  and  domestic  consultants  will  develop  detailed  curricula  and  training 
modules  in  consultation  with  Dak  Nong  provincial  leaders,  MPI,  and  ADB.  Lessons   from 
previous TAs, the planning handbook (being prepared by MPI), existing and new sector study 
reports, and the training modules developed under TA4163 and TA4252 (footnote 5) will provide

key references. The training activities will then be rolled down to districts and communes. The 
TA will reorient and retrain government officials to be more efficient and proactive in delivering 
services,  mobilizing  revenues,  and  promoting  private  sector  investment.  A  competitiveness 
index will be prepared, following the methodology developed by the Viet Nam Chamber of 
Commerce and Industry, to recently assess the provincial competitiveness of 40 provinces and 
cities in Viet Nam. 
 
9.   Expected Development Results/Outcomes. The main expected development results 
of the TA for Dak Nong would be significant improvement in poverty reduction and growth. In 
the short term, the TA will contribute to achieving (i) adoption of CPRGS elements (participatory 
and bottom-up process, results-based approach, social inclusion, etc.) in local planning; (ii) 
improvement in the business environment and proactive inward investment promotion activities; 
and (iii) strengthened institutional capabilities to undertake policy analysis, sector studies, and 
results-based socioeconomic development planning and management. 
 
10.  Major Expected Outputs. The major outputs of the TA will be (i) training workshops for 
provincial-level government officials; (ii) training modules, seminar proceedings, and guidelines 
on results-based and strategic socioeconomic development planning and management; (iii) 
sector studies on selected sectors (e.g., agriculture crop diversification, livestock, community 
development,  investment  promotion,  etc.);  (iv)  competitive  index  of  Dak  Nong;  (v) 
guide/brochure  on  investment  opportunities  in  Dak  Nong;  and  (vi)  trade  and  investment 
meetings. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
11.  The  total  cost  of  the  TA  is  estimated  at  $812,000  equivalent,  comprising  foreign 
exchange  of  $240,000  and  local  currency  equivalent  of  $572,000.  The  Government  has 
requested ADB to finance $650,000 equivalent, comprising $240,000 in foreign exchange and 
$410,000 equivalent in local currency. The TA will be financed on a grant basis from the ADB- 
administered  Poverty  Reduction  Cooperation  Fund  in  the  amount  of  $325,000  and  the 
Cooperation  Fund  in  Support  of  the  Formulation  and  Implementation  of  National  Poverty 
Reduction Strategies in the amount of $325,000. The Government will finance the balance of 
the  local  currency  costs,  amounting  to  $162,000  equivalent  in  kind  to  cover  office 
accommodation,  counterpart  staff,  administrative  and  logistic  support,  and  other  required 
services. Details of the TA cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.  The TA project will be implemented over a 2-year period. Its implementation will require 
(i) 10 person-months of international consulting services on an intermittent basis, in the fields of 
strategic development planning and results-based management, crop diversification, investment 
promotion, ethnic minority development, resource mobilization, and training; and (ii) about 36 
person-months of domestic consulting services. The outline terms of reference are in Appendix 
3.  National and provincial universities, research institutes, and nongovernment organizations 
will be considered for undertaking some envisaged activities. Consultants will be engaged as 
individuals  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants  and  other 
arrangements satisfactory to ADB for engaging domestic consultants. ADB’s Viet Nam Resident 
Mission (VRM) will administer the TA in close consultation with MPI, and the PPC and DPI of 
Dak Nong province. 
 
13.  The PPC of Dak Nong province will be the Executing Agency for the TA. The PPC will 
be responsible for overall coordination and management of the project at the provincial level,

5
including  (i)  coordinating  with  ADB  and  other  government  agencies  and  (ii)  ensuring  the 
necessary  national-level  approvals  are  obtained  in  a  timely  manner,  to  facilitate  project 
implementation. The DPI will be responsible for project implementation. The Project will be 
managed through the provincial project management unit (PPMU) to be established at the DPI. 
Coordination  will  be  provided  through  a  project  steering  committee,  chaired  by  the  vice 
chairman of the Dak Nong PPC. Committee members will include a deputy director-level official 
of the Foreign Economic Relations Department of MPI, a deputy director of the Regional and 
Local Planning Department of MPI, selected provincial sectoral departments, and VRM. The 
steering committee will meet at least biannually to review implementation progress and guide 
the project activities.   
 
14.   Evaluation  of  the  implementation  process  and  initial  outcomes  of  targeted  poverty 
reduction will be carried out through (i) periodic reviews of the province’s public investment 
plans and provincial budgets, and (ii) participatory assessment by the stakeholders to ensure 
that an adequate percentage of investments targeted the poor or related activities. Likewise, the 
PPMU will ensure that resource allocation is prioritized and directed at financing the planned 
targeted interventions. Implementation progress including initial outcomes in poverty reduction 
or on the lives of the poor will be circulated to all stakeholders through annual reports. ADB and 
the Government will carry out joint annual reviews. The consultants will prepare and submit (i) 
an inception report within 2 weeks of the start of the TA; (ii) quarterly progress reports and (iii) a 
final report at project/assignment completion.  
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering (i) technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $325,000 to be financed 
on a grant basis by the Poverty Reduction Cooperation Fund to the Government of the Socialist 
Republic of Viet Nam for Capacity Building Support to Dak Nong Province for Improving Poverty 
Reduction and Growth Performance, and (ii) technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent 
of  $325,000  to  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  the  Cooperation  Fund  in  Support  of  the 
Formulation and Implementation of National Poverty Reduction Strategies for Capacity Building 
Support to Dak Nong Province for Improving Poverty Reduction and Growth Performance, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The TA will require 46 person-months of consulting services: 10 international and 36 
domestic. The consultant skills mix is as follows (person-months): 
(i)  strategic socioeconomic development planning and results-based management 
specialist (international, 6); 
(ii)  agriculture (crop) diversification expert (international, 1) ; 
(iii)  community development expert (with focus on ethnic minorities) (international, 2); 
(iv)  investment promotion specialist (international, 1); 
(v)  project coordinator (domestic, 24); and 
(vi)  short-term consultants (domestic, 12). 
 
A.  Strategic Planning and Results-Based Management Specialist 
  (international, 6) 
 
2.  The specialist (team leader) will assist the provincial people’s committee (PPC) and 
department of planning and investment (DPI) in implementing the socioeconomic development 
plan (SEDP) for 2006–2010, particularly through annual plan preparation, taking into account 
sector and thematic priorities and potential economic opportunities from provincial, national, and 
subregional infrastructure development; and provide training in strategic planning and results-
based management to counterpart government officials. The specialist will also identify/develop 
relevant provincial-level socioeconomic and sector indicators that can be used to effectively 
monitor and evaluate the progress of SEDP implementation. It is essential that the consultant  
have a university degree, relevant skills and comprehensive experience with the issues to be 
addressed,  and  relevant  work  experience  in  developing  and  transition  economies.  Work 
experience  in  Viet  Nam  would  be  an  advantage.  Working  closely  with  the  DPI  and  other 
international and domestic consultants, the consultant will undertake these tasks: 
 
(i)  Take stock of and analyze the perceived needs from the various levels (central, 
province, district, commune), system of regulation, institutional setup regarding 
planning, and government initiatives, economic opportunities from infrastructure 
development and the natural resource endowment of the province.  
(ii)  Undertake a strength, weaknesses, opportunities, threats (SWOT) analysis of the 
province and recommend formulation of a strategy for faster but sustainable 
socioeconomic development of the province. 
(iii)  Review the currently used development planning process, budgeting process,

4.  Working closely with the project team, DPI, DARD, relevant provincial departments, local

D.  Investment Promotion Specialist (international, 1) 
 
8.  Working closely with the project team, DPI, and relevant provincial departments, local 
districts and communes, and the business community, the specialist will assess the policy 
environment for promoting inward investment, from both domestic and foreign private sector, 
taking into account (i) economic opportunities from provincial, national, and regional initiatives;  
(ii) infrastructure development; (iii) other ongoing initiatives; and (iv) institutional constraints; and 
formulate  a  program  for  promoting  investments  (with  estimated  time  and  resource 
requirements). The consultant will also assist in preparing an investors’ guide and holding 
investment promotion conferences for Dak Nong province. 
 
9.  The specialist will have at least a university degree, relevant skills and comprehensive 
experience  with  investment  promotion-related  issues  and  relevant  international  work 
experience. Work experience in Viet Nam will be an advantage.  
 
E.  Project Coordinator (domestic, 24) 
 
10.  The project coordinator will manage the project, working closely with the PPC, DPI, and 
ADB, and coordinating and facilitating the work of all other consultants. The coordinator will be 
responsible for scheduling project activities, designing and conducting training and consultation 
workshops/seminars, and collecting and compiling basic information for the project. Working 
closely  with  the  international  and  domestic  consultants,  the  coordinator  will    prepare  the 
following reports: (i) an inception report, within 2 weeks of the start of the TA; (ii) a midterm 
report, within 12 months; and (iii) a final report at project/assignment completion. Working 
closely with government counterparts and short-term domestic consultants, the coordinator will 
ensure that basic information required by international consultants for various aspects of the 
project is available before their arrival.  
 
11.  The specialist will have at least a university degree, relevant skills and comprehensive 
experience with project management, and be well-versed in national and provincial government 
policies and procedures. He/she will be fluent in written and oral English. 
 
F.  Short-Term Consultants (domestic, up to 12) 
 
12.  The  specialists  will  assist  the  international  consultants  in  their  respective  fields  of 
expertise in undertaking sector analysis and case studies, and in developing training modules. 
They will also provide inputs in training programs. 
 
13.  The specialists will have at least a university degree in environment science; relevant 
skills  and  experience  in  socioeconomic  development  planning,  participative  planning 
techniques, project cycle management, community development, investment promotion, and 
poverty reduction-related issues; and relevant international work experience. Work experience 
in Viet Nam will be an advantage.
